III.ii.2.F.5.b
.
Buddy Statements as Secondary Evidence of Involvement in Combat
Under circumstances described in
38 CFR 3.304(d)
, VA may grant SC for a disability incurred or aggravated during combat based solely on a Veteran’s assertion of the circumstances surrounding its incurrence or aggravation.
If service records do not show the Veteran was involved in combat on the date the disability was incurred or aggravated, VA may use a credible statement from a fellow service member (often referred to as a “buddy statement”) to corroborate the Veteran’s claim.
VA considers a buddy statement “credible” if the evidence of record shows the fellow service member served in the same unit and at the same time as the Veteran claims he/she was injured in combat.  This information is usually obtainable through review of the fellow service member’s
DD Form 214, Certificate of Uniformed Service
, or other evidence of service.
References
:  For more information on
obtaining evidence to verify service information of the author of a buddy statement, see
M21-1, Part III, Subpart ii, 2.F.6.b
, and
the use of buddy statements to corroborate in-service stressors, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 1.A.1.g
.
